questions.name: hh_in_any_atrisk_categories
questions.label: Household: in any at-risk categories?

tooltip.text:
INTERVIEW: is the household in any of the following at-risk household categories? Household may be in more than one category
At-risk household: defined as a household at risk of not achieving or not sustaining the required sanitation and hygiene outcomes, or at risk from the public health hazards associated with unsafely managed sanitation and hygiene services
At-risk categories: the county public health office should determine the at-risk categories to be flagged in this county. The following list includes a number of potential at-risk categories, but should be edited to match the priority at-risk categories identified by the county public health office

options.label: AT RISK: Disabled household member (mentally or physically)
AT RISK: Female-headed household (single mothers, divorcees, widows)
AT RISK: HIV/AIDS affected (or other serious illness)
AT RISK: In-migrants (new households in last 12 months)
AT RISK: New adult households (newly formed household)
AT RISK: Nomadic or semi-nomadic pastoralists
AT RISK: Orphans and vulnerable children
AT RISK: Seasonal migrants (fisherfolk, farmers etc)
AT RISK: Shared use of someone else's toilet/public toilet (don't have a toilet)
AT RISK: previously collapsed or abandoned toilets

questions.name: animals_kept_in_household_compound
questions.label: Do you keep animals in the household compound?

tooltip.text: Animals in the household compound: include poultry (chickens, turkeys, ducks, geese), goats, cattle, sheep, camels, pigs, donkeys, rabbits and any other livestock (kept for food or income-generating purposes)

questions.name: Unique_hh_characteristics
questions.label: Address or any unique household identifier

tooltip.text:
Urban : Enter house number and street name
Rural : Enter any characteristic which helps distinguish this household from other similar households in the community

questions.name: od_or_toilet_use
questions.label: 🟢 G1-1.2a : Does your household defecate in the open, or use a toilet?

tooltip.text:
INTERVIEW: Do members of your household defecate in the open or use a toilet?
Own toilet: a toilet owned by the household (usually located nearby the home)
Other household toilet: a toilet owned by another household (often on somone else's property)

options.label: Do NOT use toilet, practice open defecation

questions.name: name_household_head_other_toilet_used
questions.label: 🟢 G1-1.2b : Name the household head of the other household toilet used?

tooltip.text:
Other household toilet: enter the name of the household head who owns the other household toilet used INTERVIEW: do you share this toilet with others who are not members of your household?
Shared toilet use: shared use of a toilet is acceptable, providing that no more than 10-15 people use the toilet. The County Public Health Office should agree on the maximum number of people sharing a toilet based on local practices and evidence of hygienic outcomes in shared toilets.

questions.name: shared_toilet_use_number_of_people
questions.label: 🟢 G1-1.2c : Do you share the toilet? How many people use the toilet?

tooltip.text:
INTERVIEW: do you share this toilet with others who are not members of your household?
Shared toilet use: shared use of a toilet is acceptable, providing that no more than 10-15 people use the toilet. The County Public Health Office should agree on the maximum number of people sharing a toilet based on local practices and evidence of hygienic outcomes in shared toilets.

questions.name: households_using_toilet
questions.label: 🟢 G1-1.2d : How many other households use the toilet?

tooltip.text:
INTERVIEW: are any members of your household unable to use the toilet?
INTERVIEW (for those unable to use): are they able to use the toilet with assistance?
All use toilet: household respondent confirms that everyone EITHER uses the toilet, OR is assisted to use the toilet

questions.name: all_hh_members_use_toilet
questions.label: 🟢 G1-1.2e : Does everyone use the toilet?

tooltip.text:
INTERVIEW: are any members of your household unable to use the toilet?
INTERVIEW (for those unable to use): are they able to use the toilet with assistance?
All members use toilet: household respondent confirms that everyone EITHER uses the toilet, OR is assisted to use the toilet

questions.name: toilet_use_by_all_members_1
questions.label: 🟢 G2-1.1 : Individual use of toilet at all times (member 1)

tooltip.text:
INTERVIEW: Ask each household member individually, the last time you defecated, did you defecate in the open or use the toilet?
INTERVIEW: do any members of the household require assistance to the toilet? What sort of assistance?
PROBE: do any members of the household use the toilet sometimes, and defecate in the open at other times? In this case, response option is G0 No toilet, practice OD
REPEAT for other household members
NOTE: If household member is not available, or too young to answer (0-4 years), ask the household respondent to confirm OD or toilet use

options.label: No toilet use, practice open defecation
Some toilet use, some open defecation
Use own toilet with assistance (not shared)

questions.name: durable_toilet_containment_collection_system
questions.label: 🟢 G2-1.3 : Is the toilet pit (or tank) durable?

tooltip.text:
INTERVIEW: is the toilet pit or tank or collection system durable?
INTERVIEW (where pit or tank not visible): were any materials used to support the sides of the pit or tank system?
INTERVIEW (where not visible): does the soil collapse without support?
INTERVIEW (where pit or tank not visible): has the toilet pit collapsed in the last 12 months?
Durable toilet pit or tank (in stable soils): unlined pits may be assessed as durable in areas where other unlined pits are known to be stable and long-lasting.
Durable toilet pit or tank (in UNSTABLE soils): the pit or tank should either be lined with durable materials, or lined with resilient local materials that will not degrade rapidly under local conditions, and which provide similar lifespans and support to linings made from durable materials.

options.label: Toilet with no pit or tank (discharge to open)
Pit or tank lined with non-durable local materials
Pit lined with blocks or bricks
Pit lined with resilient local materials
Pit lined with other durable materials

questions.name: visible_surface_outflows
questions.label: 🟢 G2-1.4b : Are surface outflows from the pit ever visible?

tooltip.text: NTERVIEW: how often are surface outflows from the pit (or tank) visible? Surface outflows: wastewater or faecal sludge leaking or overflowing on the ground around the pit (or tank).

options.label: Surface outflows: Toilet with no pit or tank

questions.name: safely_managed_onsite_containment
questions.label: 🟢 G3-1.1a : has the pit (or tank) ever been emptied?

tooltip.text:
INTERVIEW: has the toilet pit (or tank) ever filled up?
INTERVIEW: what happened when the toilet pit (or tank) last filled up?
Never emptied: current pit is not yet full, and has NOT been emptied. Intention to empty: household is planning to empty toilet pit (or tank) when full, or when required

options.label: Toilet with no pit or tank (discharge to open)
Pit or tank overflows to open
Never emptied (but intention to empty when full)
Never emptied (first pit: NO intention to empty)
Never emptied ( previous pit replaced: NO intention to empty)
EMPTIED: ALL pit (or tank) contents removed
EMPTIED: SOME pit (or tank) contents removed

questions.name: safely_managed_sanitation_services
questions.label: 🟢 G3-1.1b : where were the pit (or tank) contents emptied to?

tooltip.text:
INTERVIEW: the last time it was emptied, who emptied the toilet pit (or tank)? INTERVIEW: if a lined pit or tank: what will happen when the toilet pit (or tank) is full?INTERVIEW: How long were the contents stored (without any fresh excreta entering the toilet pit or tank) before emptying?
Storage time: length of time that contents of containment were stored without any fresh excreta entering the containment (for example, alternating twin pit latrine where full pit is disconnected and contents are stored for 2 years before emptying)
Licensed service provider: paid emptier that is approved and regulated by local authority to empty and transport toilet wastes
Unlicensed service provider: paid or unpaid emptier who is NOT approved (for example, family members, neighbours, friends, informal local emptiers)
Sewer connection to licensed and functional treatment site: the Public Health Office should check whether the sewer network flows to a licensed and functional treatment or disposal site.
Open container: bucket or other open container used to collect excreta (usually regularly collected and emptied).

options.label: Toilet with no pit or tank (discharge to open)
Closed container removed by UNLICENSED worker
Emptied by UNLICENSED worker (transported out of community)
Stored for LESS than 2 years before emptying
Sewer connection to UNLICENSED or NON-FUNCTIONAL treatment site
Emptied by LICENSED worker (transported out of community)
Emptied to nearby covered pit (buried within community)
Closed container removed by LICENSED worker
Stored for MORE than 2 years before emptying
Sewer connection to LICENSED and FUNCTIONAL treatment or disposal site

questions.name: hh_toilet_observed
questions.label: 🔵 G1-1.1a : Household toilet visible?

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: Is a toilet facility visible in the house or household compound?

questions.name: photo_01_front_toilet
questions.label: TOILET PHOTO 01: outside front view (showing entire toilet: door, walls & roof)

questions.name: photo_02_back_toilet
questions.label: TOILET PHOTO 02: inside view of toilet (showing floor, pan/hole)

questions.name: functional_toilet
questions.label: 🔵 G1-1b : Functional toilet

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: is the toilet functional? Functional toilet: the toilet is functioning, and all toilet features can be used (not blocked, abandoned or collapsed). Partly functional toilet: the toilet is functioning, but some toilet features are not working as intended.

questions.name: toilet_privacy
questions.label: 🔵 G1-1c : Toilet privacy

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: does the toilet superstructure meet local criteria for privacy?
OBSERVE: are animals prevented from entering the toilet?
Privacy: toilet superstructure has walls and a door that allow use of the toilet without observation by people outside the toilet (NOTE: variations in privacy criteria may be agreed by County Public Health Office to reflect local practices).
Privacy from animals: the toilet superstructure should also prevent animals from entering the toilet, to limit contact between animals and human excreta.

questions.name: toilet_interface
questions.label: 🔵 G1-1.3a : Type of toilet interface

tooltip.text: Toilet interface: squat hole, pour-flush pan or other connected to pit (or tank). Pit or tank (or other): storage for excreta (urine and faeces)

options.label: Hole in floor (VIP latrine with vent pipe)
Flush or pour-flush pan with water seal
Open pipe to pit (no water seal)

questions.name: containment_or_collection_system
questions.label: 🔵 G1-1.3b : Type of pit, tank or connection

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: [Pit or tank (or other): storage for excreta (urine and faeces). Connection: pipe through which excreta and wastewater are collected (e.g. sewer network connection). Examples: 1. Latrine pit. 2. Septic tank. 3. Connection to sewer network. Flush to don’t know: household does not know where the toilet flushes to, but no surface outlets or open discharges are visible (in this case, likely to be a buried pit or tank).

options.label: Flush or pour-flush to don't know

questions.name: photo_04_containment_system
questions.label: TOILET PHOTO 03: if offset, view of pit or tank cover slab

questions.name: flyproof_toilet
questions.label: 🔵 G1-1.3c : Is toilet flyproof?

tooltip.text:
Flyproof: toilet design prevents flies from reaching the excreta in the pit (or tank/other) VIP vent pipe with insect screen: the top of the vent pipe should be covered with insect screen to prevent insect entry into the pit or tank.
Examples: Pour-flush pit latrine with functional water seal pan. 2. VIP latrine with screened vent pipe. 3. Dry pit latrine with tight-fitting cover on the squate hole.

options.label: Inadequate or missing cover on latrine hole
VIP vent pipe with insect screen
Broken or empty water seal (no water)
VIP vent pipe without insect screen

questions.name: clean_toilet_pandrophole
questions.label: 🔵 G1-1.4a : Clean toilet floor and pan

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: are the toilet floor and plan clean? Clean: floor and pan of the toilet should appear clean, with no visible faeces, urine or used cleaning materials (for example, toilet paper or other paper, leaves or other anal cleansing materials). Easily cleaned: minor traces of faeces or soiled materials are acceptable only if easily cleaned (for example, if a child forgot to flush the toilet; or if the traces are not yet dry and difficult to clean).

options.label: NOT clean: heavy traces of faeces or soiled cleaning materials
NOT clean: some faeces and soiled cleaning materials
Clean: minor traces of faeces or soiled materials (easily cleaned)
Clean: no visible faeces or soiled cleansing materials

questions.name: clean_toilet_walls
questions.label: 🔵 G1-1.4b : Clean toilet walls

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: are the toilet walls clean?
Clean: walls of the toilet should appear clean, with no visible faeces, urine or used cleaning materials (for example, toilet paper or other paper, leaves or other anal cleansing materials).
Easily cleaned: minor traces of faeces or soiled materials are acceptable only if easily cleaned (for example, if the traces are not yet dry and difficult to clean)

options.label: NOT clean: heavy traces of faeces
Clean: minor traces of faeces (easily cleaned)

questions.name: durable_toilet_slab
questions.label: 🔵 G2-1.2 : Durable toilet slab

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: is the toilet slab made from durable materials?
Durable toilet slab: the range of materials considered durable will depend on local contexts. The County Public Health Office should approve the use of resilient local materials that will not degrade rapidly under local conditions, and which provide similar lifespans, functionality and cleanliness to toilet slabs made from durable materials.
Examples: 1. Concrete toilet slab; 2. Concrete toilet slab covered with ceramic tiles; 3. Structural plastic slab. 4. Durable hardwood floor covered with cement.

options.label: No slab (open pit, faeces not contained)
Partial slab (openings, faeces not fully contained)

questions.name: observe_safely_managed_containment
questions.label: 🔵 G2-1.4a : Excreta contained in pit (or tank)

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: any evidence of surface outflows from the containment system (for example, visible outflows or leaks; increased vegetation growth around the pit; visible deposits from previous outflows)
Surface outflows from containment: EITHER continuous outflows of faecal sludge or wastewater from overflow pipes, holes or leaks; OR evidence of previous surface outflows (for example, increased vegetation growth around the containment system, or visible sludge deposits from overflows or leaks).
Examples of surface outflows: 1. Septic tank with overflow pipe to the surface (open space, open drain, water body); 2. Latrine pit with signs of wastewater or sludge overflow or leakage.

options.label: Single pit: not yet full (no surface outflows)
Other pit or tank (no surface outflows)
Septic tank with soakpit (no surface outflows)
Connection to sewer network (no surface outflows)

questions.name: community_low_groundwater_contamination
questions.label: G2-1C COMMUNITY LEVEL ASSESSMENT: Low risk of groundwater contamination

tooltip.text:
Community level assessment of groundwater contamination risk: the risk should be assessed by the PHO in every community, based on the information collected in the Community Form.
The PHO should inform all public health staff working in the community whether there is a High Risk or a Low Risk of groundwater contamination from sanitation in this particular community.
This risk assessment should then be selected for every household in that community. If the risk assessment has not been completed, or is not known, select High Risk

questions.name: o_r_functional_toilet_with_privacy
questions.label: G1-1.1 OUTCOME RESULT - Functional toilet with privacy

fn.fnString: #hh_toilet_observed#.includes("g1") && #functional_toilet#.includes("g1") && #toilet_privacy#.includes("g1")? "G1 Functional toilet with privacy" : "G0 Toilet non-functional or not private"

questions.name: o_r_toilet_use_by_all_hh_members
questions.label: G1-1.2 OUTCOME RESULT - Toilet use by all household members

fn.fnString: #od_or_toilet_use#.includes("g1") && #all_hh_members_use_toilet#.includes("g1") && #shared_toilet_use_number_of_people#.includes("g1") ? "G1 Toilet use by all household members"  : "G0 Toilet NOT used (or used by too many)"

questions.name: o_r_flyproof_toilet_type
questions.label: G1-1.3 OUTCOME RESULT -  Flyproof toilet type

fn.fnString: (!#toilet_interface# || #toilet_interface#.includes("g0")) && (!#containment_or_collection_system# || #containment_or_collection_system#.includes("g0")) && (!#flyproof_toilet# || #flyproof_toilet#.includes("g0")) ? "G0 Toilet NOT flyproof": "G1 Flyproof toilet"

questions.name: o_r_clean_toilet
questions.label: G1-1.4 OUTCOME RESULT - Clean toilet

fn.fnString: #clean_toilet_pandrophole#.includes("g1") && #clean_toilet_walls#.includes("g1") ? "G1 Clean toilet" : "G0 Toilet NOT clean"

questions.name: o_r_flyproof_and_clean_toilet
questions.label: G1-1.5 OUTCOME RESULT - Use of flyproof and clean toilet

fn.fnString: (!#o_r_flyproof_toilet_type# || #o_r_flyproof_toilet_type#.includes("G0")) && (!#o_r_toilet_use_by_all_hh_members# || #o_r_toilet_use_by_all_hh_members#.includes("G0")) && (!#o_r_functional_toilet_with_privacy# || #o_r_functional_toilet_with_privacy#.includes("G0")) && (!#o_r_clean_toilet# || #o_r_clean_toilet#.includes("G0")) ? "G0 Toilet NOT flyproof and clean" : "G1 Use of flyproof and clean toilet"

questions.name: o_r_individual_use_of_own_hh_toilet

questions.name: handwashing_facility_observed
questions.label: 🔵 🟢 G1-2.1a : presence of handwashing facility

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: presence and location of handwashing facility
INTERVIEW: where do you and other members of your household most often wash your hands?
INTERVIEW: is there only one handwashing facility, or are other facilities available?

options.label: Portable handwashing facility (basin, jug, jerrycan, container)

questions.name: photo_01_entire_facility
questions.label: HANDWASHING PHOTO 01: view of entire facility (water container/tap, soap)
questions.short_label: PHOTO: of handwashing facility nearest to toilet

tooltip.text: PHOTO: of handwashing facility nearest to toilet

questions.name: functional_hwf
questions.label: 🔵 G1-2.1b : Functional handwashing facility

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: is the handwashing facility functional? Functional handwashing facility: the facility is functioning as intended, and all handwashing features can be used (not blocked, abandoned or unable to work).
Partly functional handwashing facility: the facility is functioning, but some features of the facility are not working as intended.

questions.name: water_available_at_hwf
questions.label: 🔵 G1-2.2 : Water available at handwashing facility

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: is water available at the handwashing facility? INTERVIEW: is water always available for washing hands (even in dry season)? Evidence of washing: where an empty water container is observed at the handwashing facility, visible wet ground (or wet materials) under the handwashing facility can be accepted as proof of the recent presence of water.

questions.name: soap_available_at_hwf
questions.label: 🔵 G1-2.3 : Soap available at handwashing facility

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: is soap available at the handwashing facility?
INTERVIEW: is soap or detergent available in your household for washing hands?
Soap: solid, liquid or powder soap or detergent

options.label: No soap or other cleanser available
Soap in house, NOT at handwashing facility
Solid, liquid or powder soap available

questions.name: handwashing_facility_type
questions.label: 🔵 G3-2.1 : Handwashing facility type

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: what type of handwashing facility is used? Permanent handwashing station: facility made from durable materials, with piped water connection or adequate water storage, and located in a fixed place that is appropriate for handwashing at critical times.
Temporary handwashing facility: tippy tap or other facility made from non-durable materials.
Portable bowl: open container that can be picked up and moved.

options.label: Jerrycan (or other closed container) with NO lid
Jerrycan (or other closed container) with lid
Portable bowl or other open container
Permanent handwashing station with water storage

questions.name: handsfree_operation_of_handwashing_facility
questions.label: 🔵 G3-2.2 : Hands-free handwashing facility

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: mechanism to collect water or trigger water flow
Hands-free operation: the handwashing station is operated by tap, or other hands-free mechanism that minimises contact with the water collection device and the water container

options.label: Water collected using a tool (ladle, cup, other)
Closed water storage container with tap

questions.name: adequate_drainage_of_washing_water
questions.label: 🔵 G3-2.3 : Drainage of washing water

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: facility to collect washing water, and facility to drain and dispose of the washing water
Collection of washing water: container to collect dirty washing water (for example, a basin or other container)
Drainage and disposal of washing water: drainage pipe or other facility to direct the washing water to an appropriate disposal point (for example, a soakpit or drain)

options.label: No collection or disposal of washing water
Collection of washing water without good drainage or disposal
Safe collection and disposal of washing water

questions.name: handwashing_critical_toilet_times
questions.label: 🟢 G2-2.1 : When do you usually wash your hands? Note critical TOILET times

tooltip.text:
INTERVIEW: when do you usually wash your hands?
INTERVIEW: what do you usually use to wash your hands?
Critical TOILET times: washing of hands with soap and water AFTER toilet use and AFTER anal cleansing.
NOTE: households should mention critical handwashing times without being prompted by the monitor

options.label: Do NOT use soap and water
No mention of critical TOILET times

questions.name: handwashing_critical_food_times
questions.label: 🟢 G2-2.2 : When do you usually wash your hands? Note critical FOOD times

tooltip.text:
INTERVIEW: what do you usually use to wash your hands? Assessment: if the household confirms handwashing with soap and water, note whether any of the critical times (related to toilets, food, infant excreta and animals) are mentioned.
Ask about “an other times when you wash your hands?” but DO NOT make suggestions. Critical FOOD times: washing of hands with soap and water BEFORE food preparation or cooking; BEFORE feeding infants or young children; and BEFORE eating.

options.label: Do NOT use soap and water
No mention of critical FOOD times
Before eating, food preparation and feeding children

questions.name: handwashing_critical_infant_times
questions.label: 🟢 G2-2.3 : When do you usually wash your hands? Note critical INFANT EXCRETA times

tooltip.text:
INTERVIEW: what do you usually use to wash your hands? Assessment: if the household confirms handwashing with soap and water, note whether any of the critical times (related to toilets, food, infant excreta and animals) are mentioned.
Ask about “an other times when you wash your hands?” but DO NOT make suggestions. Critical INFANT times: washing of hands with soap and water by caregivers AFTER cleaning an infant of excreta, AFTER handling child faeces, or AFTER washing or disposing of a used diaper

options.label: GDo NOT use soap and water
No mention of critical INFANT EXCRETA times
After ANY contact with infant excreta or soiled diapers

questions.name: handwashing_critical_animal_times
questions.label: 🟢 G2-2.4 : When do you usually wash your hands? Note critical ANIMAL times

tooltip.text:
INTERVIEW: what do you usually use to wash your hands? Assessment: if the household confirms handwashing with soap and water, note whether any of the critical times (related to toilets, food, infant excreta and animals) are mentioned.
Ask about “an other times when you wash your hands?” but DO NOT make suggestions. Critical ANIMAL times: washing of hands with soap and water AFTER contact with animals, animal products or animal wastes; and both BEFORE and AFTER milking (in households that milk animals)

options.label: Do NOT use soap and water
No mention of critical ANIMAL times
After ANY contact with animals, animal products or animal wastes

questions.name: no_exposed_human_excreta_in_compound
questions.label: 🔵 G1-3.1 : No exposed human excreta in compound

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: any visible human faeces (OD) in the compound, house, toilet or in any other household buildings or facilities.
Open defecation in water bodies: where groups or communities may practice open defecation in nearby water bodies (for example, people living near beaches, lakes and rivers), human excreta may not be visible in and around household compounds or communal areas. In these cases, household interviews should be undertaken to assess whether people practice open defecation or use a toilet, in combination of observation of the presence of a functional toilet (to verify claims of toilet use).

options.label: Child or adult excreta observed in the compound
No visible human excreta (child or adult) in compound

questions.name: safe_management_of_child_excreta_in_compound
questions.label: 🟢 G1-4.1 : Safe management of child excreta in compound

tooltip.text: INTERVIEW: the last time [name of youngest child] defecated, where did they defecate? INTERVIEW: what happened to the child faeces after defecation? If collected, where were the child faeces disposed? INTERVIEW: If a collection tool was used, was it washed safely?Child excreta: faeces or urine of children who are considered too young to use a toilet easily Unsafely washed: washing of dirty collection tools (for example, potty or shovel) in household compound, at a water point, without safe disposal of the contaminated washing water. Unsafely disposed: child faeces diposed to open space, field, open drain, water body.

options.label: Child faeces disposed with solid waste
Child faeces unsafely handled (potty or collection tool unsafely washed)
Child faeces put or rinsed into toilet
Other safe management of child excreta

questions.name: safe_management_of_diapers_in_compound
questions.label: 🔵 🟢 G1-4.2 : Safe management of used diapers in compound

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: are any used diapers visible in the compound? INTERVIEW: the last time [name of youngest child] defecated, were the faeces contained by a cloth or a diaper? INTERVIEW: if a washable cloth was used, where was the cloth cleaned and washed?
And how were any faeces on the cloth disposed? INTERVIEW: if a disposable diaper was used, what happened to the used diaper? Safe management of used diapers: where disposable diapers are used to contain child excreta,
the used diapers should be properly closed and EITHER disposed to a covered waste pit, OR buried, OR collected for disposal at a safely managed communal disposal site. Safe management of washable cloths: where washable cloths are used to contain child excreta, the used cloths should be cleaned and washed in a safe place (for example, so that the child excreta do not contaminate the household compound or a water point)
and any faeces contained in the cloth should be safely disposed (for example, put or rinsed into the toilet, or buried). Used diapers put in the toilet pit: used diapers should not be disposed into a toilet pit because they do not degrade, and may cause the pit to fill up rapidly.

options.label: Used diapers visible in the compound
Used diapers unsafely disposed or unsafely washed
Used diapers put in the toilet pit
Used diapers put into covered waste pit
Used diapers collected and safely stored for disposal at communal site
Washable cloths safely emptied and safely washed

questions.name: clean_food
questions.label: 🔵 G2-3.1a : Clean food

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: cleanliness of raw food, produce and cooked food
Clean food: raw food (for example, fruit and vegetables) should be washed to remove dirt or other contamination before preparing, cooking or storing

questions.name: covered_food_storage
questions.label: 🔵 G2-3.1b : Covered food storage

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: covered storage of raw food, produce and cooked food Covered food storage: food should be stored in covered storage (for example, in cupboards, shelves, boxes or containers)
inside the house (or kitchen), and be protected from contact with animals

questions.name: raised_food_storage
questions.label: 🔵 G2-3.1c : Raised food storage

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: raised storage of raw food, produce and cooked food
Raised food storage: food should be stored off the ground, inside the house (or kitchen), and protected from animal contact in raised storage (for example, cupboards, shelves, boxes and containers)

questions.name: clean_kitchen_utensils
questions.label: 🔵 G2-3.2a : Clean kitchen utensils

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: cleanliness of kitchen utensils Clean kitchen utensils: kitchen utensils (for example, pots, pans, plates, cutlery, glasses and any cutting, stirring or serving tools) are washed and clean before storage or re-use.

questions.name: covered_utensil_storage
questions.label: 🔵 G2-3.2b : Covered utensil storage

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: Covered storage of kitchen utensilsCovered kitchen utensil storage:kitchen utensils should be stored in covered storage (for example, cupboards, shelves, boxes and containers) inside the house (or kitchen), and protected from animal contact

questions.name: raised_utensil_storage
questions.label: 🔵 G2-3.2c : Raised utensil storage

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: raised storage of kitchen utensilsRaised kitchen utensil storage: kitchen utensils should be stored off the ground, inside the house (or kitchen), and protected from animal contact in raised storage (for example, cupboards, shelves, boxes and containers)

questions.name: clean_milk_containers
questions.label: 🔵 G2-3.3a : Clean milk containers

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: cleanliness of empty milk containers
Clean milk containers: the containers used to collect and store milk should be thoroughly washed before each milking, so that they are free of dirt and other contamination

questions.name: covered_container_storage
questions.label: 🔵 G2-3.3b : Covered milk container storage

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: covered storage of empty milk containers
Covered milk container storage: empty milk containers should be stored in covered storage (for example, cupboards, shelves, boxes and containers) inside the house (or kitchen), and protected from animal contact

questions.name: raised_container_storage
questions.label: 🔵 G2-3.3c : Raised milk container storage

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: raised storage of empty milk containers
Raised milk container storage: empty milk containers should be stored off the ground, inside the house (or kitchen), and protected from animal contact in raised storage (for example, cupboards, shelves, boxes and containers)

questions.name: clean_water_containers
questions.label: 🔵 G2-4.1a : Clean water containers

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: cleanliness of empty water containers
Clean water containers: the containers used to collect water should be thoroughly washed before each water collection, so that they are free of dirt and other contamination

questions.name: adequate_water_quality
questions.label: 🟢 G2-4.1b : Good water quality

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: quality of drinking water
INTERVIEW: is the water supplied by your main source usually of acceptable quality?
INTERVIEW: what do you usually do to the water to make it safe to drink? [Options: boil, add chlorine, strain through cloth, use water filter, solar disinfection, settlement, other, NOT required]
Adequate quality at collection point: water is collected from protected groundwater sources (for example, covered wells, protected boreholes, or protected water points); OR is treated surface water (e.g. treated by use of chlorine dispensers)
Household water treatment: water is settled, filtered, boiled, solar disinfected, or chemically treated (for example, by use of chlorine solution or tablets) by the household

options.label: Good water quality at collection point

questions.name: safely_stored_drinking_water
questions.label: 🔵 G2-4.1c : Safely stored drinking water

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: safe storage of drinking water
Safe drinking water storage: drinking water is stored in clean, covered containers, separate from the water used for other purposes, and away from animals

questions.name: safely_used_water
questions.label: 🔵 G2-4.1d : Safely used water

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: safe use of drinking water
Safe drinking water use: drinking water is collected and used from containers with spigots and taps, or from narrow-mouthed containers, or using a clean utensil that is only used for water collection

options.label: Water containers with taps (or spigot pipes)

questions.name: clean_water_points
questions.label: 🔵 G2-4.2a : Clean water point

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: cleanliness of water points in compound
Clean water points: free from debris, solid waste, human or animal faeces, and any other potential sources of contamination

questions.name: protected_water_points
questions.label: 🔵 G2-4.2b : Protected water point

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: protection of water points in compound
Protected surface water sources (pans, dams, lakes, rivers): fenced to prevent animal access
Protected water supply source catchments: protected from wastes and pollutants, including human excreta and animal wastes (for example, by excluding animals and prohibiting unsafe activities, such as the use of manure or chemical fertilisers in areas around water supply sources).
Protected water points: provide separate water troughs for animal watering
Protected groundwater sources (springs, wells, handpumps, boreholes): protected from contamination, wastes and pollutants (for example, by the construction of a spring box, raised parapet wall and cover, wellhead protection and sealed borehole casing).

questions.name: well_drained_water_points
questions.label: 🔵 G2-4.2c : Well drained water point

tooltip.text: Good drainage of water points: no standing water visible at or around the water source (provision of drainage and soakpits may be required in slow-draining soils)

options.label: Permanent standing water around water point
Some standing water around water point

question_groups.name: safe_management_of_animals_and_animal_wastes
question_groups.label: OBSERVATION: Safe management of animals and animal wastes

questions.name: no_animal_wastes_in_house
questions.label: 🔵 G2-5.1a: No animal wastes in house

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: presence of unsafely managed animal wastes inside house or kitchen
Animal wastes: include animal faeces and urine, animal bedding, spilled feed and water, contaminated washing water and other wastewater, and animal parts or products (for example, blood, skins, feathers, organs). These wastes may be combined, or separate, depending on local practices.
Safely managed animal wastes: the house and household compound should be free of animal wastes, except in areas where manure is properly stored and managed. Regular collection of animal wastes (for example, daily collection of animal faeces and other wastes) should be evident from observation of the house and household compound

options.label: No animal wastes in house or in kitchen

questions.name: no_animal_wastes_in_compound
questions.label: 🔵 G2-5.1b : No animal wastes in compound

tooltip.text: Safely managed animal wastes: the household compound should be free of animal wastes, except in areas where manure is properly stored and managed. Regular collection of animal wastes (for example, daily collection of animal faeces and other wastes) should be evident from observation of the household compound.

questions.name: safely_managed_animal_waste_storage
questions.label: 🔵 G2-5.2a : Presence of animal waste storage area

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: storage of animal wastes in the compound
Animal wastes: include animal faeces and urine, animal bedding, spilled feed and water, contaminated washing water and other wastewater, and animal parts or products (for example, blood, skins, feathers, organs). These wastes may be combined, or separate, depending on local practices.
Animal wastes not accessible by animals or children: any animal waste facility should prevent animal and child access to the wastes.

options.label: Animal waste NOT collected or stored
Some animal waste NOT collected or stored

questions.name: safe_location_of_animal_waste_storage
questions.label: 🔵 G2-5.2b : Safe location of animal waste storage

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: location of animal waste storage in the compound
Animal wastes: include animal faeces and urine, animal bedding, spilled feed and water, contaminated washing water and other wastewater, and animal parts or products (for example, blood, skins, feathers, organs). These wastes may be combined, or separate, depending on local practices.
Animal waste storage: animal wastes should be collected and stored in an appropriate facility located away from the house, and away from child play areas.

options.label: Unsafe place for animal waste storage
Animal waste storage close to house
Animal waste storage away from house and play areas

questions.name: safe_management_of_animal_waste_storage
questions.label: 🔵 G2-5.2c : Safe management of animal waste storage

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: leakage or discharge of solid or liquid animal wastes into the area around the animal waste storage facility
Animal wastes: include animal faeces and urine, animal bedding, spilled feed and water, contaminated washing water and other wastewater, and animal parts or products (for example, blood, skins, feathers, organs). These wastes may be combined, or separate, depending on local practices.

options.label: Animal waste storage is UNSAFELY managed
Some animal waste leaks or discharges

questions.name: location_animals_in_compound
questions.label: 🔵 G2-5.3a : Location of animals in compound

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: location of animals and animal pens
Location of animal pens: facility to confine animals, which should be located away from the house and away from child play areas (in small compounds, animals should be penned as far away as possible from the house)

options.label: Animals penned close to house or play areas
Animals penned away from house and play areas

questions.name: safe_confinement_of_animals
questions.label: 🔵 G2-5.3b : Safe confinement of animals

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: confinement of animals within pens
Confinement in animal pens: facility to confine animals, which should prevent animals from entering the home or other parts of the compound. The animal pens should limit the contamination of other parts of the compound with animal wastes, and limit contact between infants and animals.
Inadequate animal pens: do not adequately limit the movement of animals or animal wastes within the compound

questions.name: soakpit_for_liquid_wastes
questions.label: 🔵 G3-3.1a : Soakpit for liquid wastes

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: use of soakpits or drainage to manage liquid wastes and wastewater
Liquid wastes: wastewater including washing water and other liquid wastes from household activities such as food preparation, washing and bathing. Wastewater from toilets should generally be kept separate from other household liquid wastes (as it presents a higher public health hazard).

questions.name: drainage_for_stormwater
questions.label: 🔵 G3-3.1b : Drainage of stormwater

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: erosion or other damage caused by stormwater flows
Stormwater: surface water from rainfall or storms.
Adequate stormwater drainage: drains or other services that limit or prevent erosion from stormwater flows (for example, EITHER by transporting flows away from the compound, OR by encouraging infiltration into the soil)

questions.name: no_visible_solid_wastes
questions.label: 🔵 G3-3.2a : No visible solid wastes

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: visible solid wastes in compound
Solid wastes: food wastes, paper, plastic, rags, metal, glass and other solid materials discarded by the household

options.label: Clean compound with no visible solid wastes

questions.name: solid_waste_facility_or_service
questions.label: 🔵 G3-3.2b : Solid waste facility or service

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: facility (or service) for solid waste collection, management and disposal
Solid wastes: food wastes, paper, plastic, rags, metal, glass and other solid materials discarded by the household
Solid waste facility or service: covered waste pits in compound, central waste disposal site, or other waste collection service

options.label: Good solid waste storage or disposal system

questions.name: good_vector_control
questions.label: 🔵 🟢 G3-3.3 : Good vector control

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: is standing water visible in compound? INTERVIEW: where standing water provides larval breeding sites, are vector treatment or other vector control activities used to limit mosquito breeding?
INTERVIEW: is standing water visible at any time of the year? Standing water: accumulation of wastewater (or stormwater) in compound, which does NOT immediately drain away
No standing water: wastewater (or stormwater) is not currently visible in the compound, and is not visible at any time of the year Larval breeding sites: locations where mosquitoes lay eggs directly in or near water, soil and at the base of plants in places that may fill with water.Vector control activities: draining of standing water; covering of water storage containers; filling of depressions that hold water; filling of cracks in water tank and septic tank covers; covering of open vents or plumbing pipes (with insect screen).
Vector treatment activities: use of larvicides to treat bodies of water that will not be used for drinking, and which cannot be covered, emptied or removed; use of fogging or surface applications to control adult mosquitoes.

options.label: Some standing water (untreated or inadequate treatment)
Treated or managed larval breeding sites

questions.name: clean_faces
questions.label: 🔵 G3-4.1a : Clean faces

tooltip.text: OBSERVE: clean faces assessed by observation of the faces of all under-5 children in the household, and the face of the main caregiver. If one of the under-5 children or the main caregiver does not have a clean face, the outcome is NOT achieved. Clean face: no visible dirt on face.

questions.name: clean_hands
questions.label: 🔵 G3-4.1b : Clean hands

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: clean hands assessed by observation of the hands of all under-5 children in the household, and the hands of the main caregiver. If one of the under-5 children or the main caregiver does not have clean hands, the outcome is NOT achieved.
Clean hands: no visible dirt on hands.

questions.name: adequate_washing_place
questions.label: 🔵 G3-4.2a : Adequate washing place for menstrual hygiene

tooltip.text:
INTERVIEW: is there anyone in the household who has menstrual periods? OBSERVE: washing place adequate for menstrual hygiene?
Clean and private washing place: private and clean place for washing and menstrual hygiene, with water and soap available. Inadequate washing place: not private, or not clean, or without soap and water at some times

questions.name: menstrual_hygiene_disposal_site
questions.label: 🔵 G3-4.2b : Safe disposal site for menstrual hygiene wastes

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: disposal site for menstrual hygiene wastes
Disposal site: appropriate facility for the safe disposal of menstrual hygiene wastes (for example, covered bins)

questions.name: availability_of_hygiene_materials
questions.label: 🔵 G3-4.2c : Availability of menstrual hygiene materials

tooltip.text:
INTERVIEW: are menstrual hygiene materials available?
Menstrual hygiene materials and products: disposable and reusable sanitary pads, tampons, and resuable menstrual cups, clean piece of cotton cloth or cotton wool, that are safe and hygienic, and absorb or collect blood during menstrual periods.
Available: menstrual hygiene materials are currently available on premises (in the home or household compound)

options.label: Materials are NOT available or NOT appropriate
Materials are not always available or appropriate

questions.name: fully_immunized_children
questions.label: 🔵 🟢 G3-5.1 : Fully immunized children

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: vaccination records or certificates
Fully immunized children: all under-5 children in the household have received the relevant vaccinations

questions.name: vitamin_a_supplements_received
questions.label: 🔵 🟢 G3-5.2 : Vitamin A supplements received

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: Vitamin A supplement records
Vitamin A supplements: all under-5 children should receive Vitamin A supplements every 6 months, and mothers should receive Vitamin A supplements within 6 weeks of delivery to pass the vitamin on to the child through breast milk.
Vitamin A supplements received: confirm that all under-5 children in the household have received a Vitamin A supplement in the last 6 months

options.label: Some vitamin A supplements not received (in last 6 months)
All vitamin A supplements received in last 6 months

questions.name: exclusive_breastfeeding_under_6_months
questions.label: 🔵 G3-5.3 : Exclusive breastfeeding for under 6-month children

tooltip.text:
INTERVIEW (to mothers of under 6 month old babies): how are you feeding your baby? [Options: Exclusive breastfeeding, breastfeeding and milk substitutes; milk substitutes only; other]
INTERVIEW (to mothers of under 6 month old babies): Has your baby been given anything other than breast milk since it was born
Exclusive breastfeeding: infants should receive only breast milk until 6 months old. No other food or water should be given to the infant during the first 6-month period, because of the risk that this food or water may be contaminated and cause illness.
Exclusive breastfeeding for under 6-month children: assess by interview, supported by observation of the foods available in the house to confirm the reported diet of the under-2 children

options.label: Under 6-month children regularly receive water or other food
Some water and other food received on a few occasions

questions.name: nutritious_diet_6m_2y
questions.label: 🔵 G3-5.4 : Nutritious diet for 6-month to 2-year old children

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: what food types/groups are present in the home?
INTERVIEW (to mothers of under 2 year children): which of these foods have been fed to your under-2 children in the last 7 days?
Nutritious diet: all 6-month to under-2 children received foods from 5 or more food groups during the previous day
Nutritious diet assessment: by household interview, supported by observation of the foods available in the house (to confirm reported diet of under-2 children)
Nutritious food groups: 1. Breast milk 2. Grains, white roots, tubers and plaintains 3. Legumes and nuts 4. Dairy 5. Flesh foods (meat, fish, poultry, liver and organ meats) 6. Eggs 7. Vitamin A rich fruits and vegetables (for example, sweet potato, kale, carrot, red pepper, mango, pink grapefruit, watermelon) 8. Other fruits and vegetables.

options.label: Some or all children eat from only 1-2 food groups
Some or all children eat from 3-4 food groups
Nutritious diet (5 or more food groups)

questions.name: malariasafe_home
questions.label: 🔵 G3-E1 : Malaria-safe home

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: insecticide-treated bed nets on all beds
OBSERVE: insect screen on windows, doors and other openings
Malaria-safe home: EITHER all household members sleep under an insecticide-treated bed net, OR the house has insect screen on all windows, doors and other openings.

options.label: No bed nets and no insect screen
Some beds without nets, or some openings unprotected

questions.name: dewormed_home
questions.label: 🔵 G3-E2 : Dewormed home

tooltip.text:
OBSERVE: deworming treatment records
Dewormed home: all children and all at-risk adults have received deworming treatment in the last 12 months

options.label: Some children or adults not treated
Dewormed home (all treated in last 12 months)

questions.name: o_r_no_exposed_human_excreta
questions.label: G1-3 OUTCOME RESULT: No exposed human excreta

fn.fnString: #no_exposed_human_excreta_in_compound#.includes("g1") ? "G1 No exposed human excreta in compound" : "G0 Child or adult excreta observed in compound"

questions.name: o_r_safe_management_of_child_excreta_and_diapers
questions.label: G1-4 OUTCOME RESULT: Safe Management of child excreta and diapers

fn.fnString: #safe_management_of_child_excreta_in_compound#.includes("g1") && #safe_management_of_diapers_in_compound#.includes("g1") ? "G1 Safely managed child excreta and diapers" : "G0 Child excreta and diapers UNSAFELY managed"

questions.name: o_r_clean_and_safely_stored_food
questions.label: G2-3.1 OUTCOME RESULT - Clean and safely stored food

fn.fnString: #clean_food#.includes("g0") && #covered_food_storage#.includes("g0") && #raised_food_storage#.includes("g0") ? "G0 Food not clean and not safely stored"  : #clean_food#.includes("g2") && #covered_food_storage#.includes("g2") && #raised_food_storage#.includes("g2") ? "G2 Clean and safely stored food" : "G1 Food not adequately washed, or not safely stored"

questions.name: o_r_clean_and_safely_stored_kitchen_utensils
questions.label: G2-3.2 OUTCOME RESULT - Clean and safely stored kitchen utensils

fn.fnString: #clean_kitchen_utensils#.includes("g0") && #covered_utensil_storage#.includes("g0") && #raised_utensil_storage#.includes("g0") ? "G0 Kitchen utensils not clean and not safely stored" : #clean_kitchen_utensils#.includes("g2") && #covered_utensil_storage#.includes("g2") && #raised_utensil_storage#.includes("g2") ? "G2 Clean and safely stored kitchen utensils" : "G1 Kitchen utensils not adequately washed, or not safely stored"

questions.name: o_r_clean_and_safely_stored_milk_containers
questions.label: G2-3.3 OUTCOME RESULT - Clean and safely stored milk containers

fn.fnString: #clean_milk_containers#.includes("g0") && #covered_container_storage#.includes("g0") && #raised_container_storage#.includes("g0") ? "G0 Milk containers not clean and not safely stored" : #clean_milk_containers#.includes("g2") && #covered_container_storage#.includes("g2") && #raised_container_storage#.includes("g2") ? "G2 Clean and safely stored milk containers" : "G1 Milk containers not adequately washed, or not safely stored"

questions.name: o_r_safe_food_hygiene
questions.label: G2-3 OUTCOME RESULT - Safe food hygiene (Household)

fn.fnString: #o_r_clean_and_safely_stored_food#.includes("G0") && #o_r_clean_and_safely_stored_kitchen_utensils#.includes("G0") && #o_r_clean_and_safely_stored_milk_containers#.includes("G0") ? "G0" : #o_r_clean_and_safely_stored_food#.includes("G2") && #o_r_clean_and_safely_stored_milk_containers#.includes("G2") && #o_r_clean_and_safely_stored_kitchen_utensils#.includes("G2") ? "G2" : "G1"

questions.name: o_r_safe_management_of_drinking_water
questions.label: G2-4.1 OUTCOME RESULT - Safe management of drinking water

fn.fnString: #clean_water_containers#.includes("g0") && #adequate_water_quality#.includes("g0") && #safely_stored_drinking_water#.includes("g0") && #safely_used_water#.includes("g0") ? "G0 Drinking water is UNSAFELY managed"  : #clean_water_containers#.includes("g2") && #adequate_water_quality#.includes("g2") && #safely_stored_drinking_water#.includes("g2") && #safely_used_water#.includes("g2") ? "G2 Safe management of drinking water" : "G1 Drinking water is NOT adequately managed"

questions.name: o_r_safe_management_of_water_sources
questions.label: G2-4.2 OUTCOME RESULT - Safe management of water sources

fn.fnString: #clean_water_points#.includes("g0") && #protected_water_points#.includes("g0") && #well_drained_water_points#.includes("g0") ? "G0 Water points are UNSAFELY managed" : #clean_water_points#.includes("g2") && #protected_water_points#.includes("g2") && #well_drained_water_points#.includes("g2") ? "G2 Safe management of water points" : "G1 Water points are NOT adequately managed"

questions.name: o_r_safe_water_management
questions.label: G2-4 OUTCOME RESULT - Safe water management (Household)

fn.fnString: #o_r_safe_management_of_drinking_water#.includes("G0") && #o_r_safe_management_of_water_sources#.includes("G0") ? "G0 Water is UNSAFELY managed" : #o_r_safe_management_of_drinking_water#.includes("G2") && #o_r_safe_management_of_water_sources#.includes("G2") ? "G2 Safe management of water" : "G1 Water is NOT adequately managed"

questions.name: o_r_no_visible_animal_wastes_in_house_or_compound
questions.label: G2-5.1 OUTCOME RESULT - No visible animal wastes in house or compound

fn.fnString: #monitor_G2#.includes("yes") && #no_animal_wastes_in_house#.includes("g0") && #no_animal_wastes_in_compound#.includes("g0") ? "G0 Widespread presence of animal wastes" : #no_animal_wastes_in_house#.includes("g2") && #no_animal_wastes_in_compound#.includes("g2") ? "G2 No visible animal wastes" : "G1 Some animal wastes visible"

questions.name: o_r_safe_management_of_animal_wastes_in_compound
questions.label: G2-5.2 OUTCOME RESULT - Safe management of animal wastes in compound

fn.fnString: #monitor_G2#.includes("yes") && #safely_managed_animal_waste_storage#.includes("g0") && #safe_location_of_animal_waste_storage#.includes("g0") && #safe_management_of_animal_waste_storage#.includes("g0") ? "G0 Animal wastes UNSAFELY managed" : #safely_managed_animal_waste_storage#.includes("g2") && #safe_location_of_animal_waste_storage#.includes("g2") && #safe_management_of_animal_waste_storage#.includes("g2") ? "G2 Safely managed animal wastes" : "G1 Inadequate management of animal wastes"

questions.name: o_r_safe_separation_of_animals_from_under5_children
questions.label: G2-5.3 OUTCOME RESULT - Safe separation of animals from under-5 children

fn.fnString: #monitor_G2#.includes("yes") && #location_animals_in_compound#.includes("g0") && #safe_confinement_of_animals#.includes("g0") ? "G0 Animals NOT separated from under-5 children" : #location_animals_in_compound#.includes("g2") && #safe_confinement_of_animals#.includes("g2") ? "G2 Safe separation of animals from under-5 children" : "G1 Inadequate separation of animals from under-5 children"

questions.name: o_r_safe_management_of_animals_wastes
questions.label: G2-5 OUTCOME RESULT - Safe management of animals and animal wastes (Household)

fn.fnString: #monitor_G2#.includes("yes") && #o_r_no_visible_animal_wastes_in_house_or_compound#.includes("G2") && #o_r_safe_separation_of_animals_from_under5_children#.includes("G2") &&  #o_r_safe_management_of_animal_wastes_in_compound#.includes("G2") ? "G2 Safe management of animals and animal wastes" : "G0 No safe management of animals and animal wastes"

questions.name: o_r_safe_management_of_liquid_wastes
questions.label: G3-3.1 OUTCOME RESULT - Safe management of liquid wastes

fn.fnString: #soakpit_for_liquid_wastes#.includes("g0") && #drainage_for_stormwater#.includes("g0") ? "G1 Liquid wastes UNSAFELY managed"  : #soakpit_for_liquid_wastes#.includes("g3") && #drainage_for_stormwater#.includes("g3") ? "G3 Safe management of liquid wastes" : "G2 Inadequate management of liquid wastes"

questions.name: o_r_safe_management_of_solid_wastes
questions.label: G3-3.2 OUTCOME RESULT - Safe management of solid wastes

fn.fnString: #no_visible_solid_wastes#.includes("g0") && #solid_waste_facility_or_service#.includes("g0") ? "G1 Solid wastes UNSAFELY managed" : #no_visible_solid_wastes#.includes("g3") && #solid_waste_facility_or_service#.includes("g3") ? "G3 Safe management of solid wastes" : "G2 Inadequate management of solid wastes"

questions.name: o_r_good_vector_control_in_compound
questions.label: G3-3.3 OUTCOME RESULT - Good vector control in compound

fn.fnString: #good_vector_control#.includes("g0") ? "G1 Lack of vector control" : #good_vector_control#.includes("g3") ? "G3 Good vector control" : "G2 Inadequate vector control"

questions.name: o_r_safe_waste_management
questions.label: G3-3 OUTCOME RESULT - Safe waste management

fn.fnString: #o_r_safe_management_of_liquid_wastes#.includes("G1") && #o_r_safe_management_of_solid_wastes#.includes("G1") && #o_r_good_vector_control_in_compound#.includes("G1") ? "G1" : #o_r_safe_management_of_liquid_wastes#.includes("G3") && #o_r_safe_management_of_solid_wastes#.includes("G3") && #o_r_good_vector_control_in_compound#.includes("G3") ? "G3" : "G2"

questions.name: o_r_clean_face_and_hands
questions.label: G3-4.1 OUTCOME RESULT - Clean face and hands

fn.fnString: #monitor_G3#.includes("yes") && #clean_faces#.includes("g1") && #clean_hands#.includes("g1") ? "G1 No personal hygiene" : #clean_faces#.includes("g3") && #clean_hands#.includes("g3") ? "G3 Good personal hygiene" : "G2 Inadequate personal hygiene"

questions.name: o_r_good_menstrual_health
questions.label: G3-4.2 OUTCOME RESULT - Good menstrual health

fn.fnString: #adequate_washing_place#.includes("g1") && #menstrual_hygiene_disposal_site#.includes("g1") && #availability_of_hygiene_materials#.includes("g1") ?
